class.name: Dragonblade (Tanares)
class.proficiency: Constitution, Intelligence, Arcana, History, Investigation, Nature, Perception, Religion
class.armor: Light Armor, Medium Armor, Heavy Armor, Shields

trait.name: Dragonblade
trait.text:
A human stands atop a towering wall, surveying the battlefield below with piercing eyes. An army of undead advances steadily, marching towards their stronghold with a relentless pace. The human remains calm, a steely determination in his gaze as he descends the stairs, his battle plan already forming in his mind. An ancient tome, bound in dragon scales, slams shut with a resounding thud. Outside, the gnome's friends call for help, but he only smiles, ready for action−his sixty years of dragon studies have given him the claws and fangs of a draconic predator. The Arena floor trembles with the chaos of battle as members of the team fall one by one. An elf retreats, his every move watched by his enemies. But his retreat is a ruse, a clever ploy to position himself for the perfect strike. With a dash and flash of his sword, he dispatches the enemy conjurors and charges forward, ready to end the battle and protect his wounded allies. Masters of draconic power and strategic thinking, these skilled combatants protect Tanares from penumbral cultists and creatures, serving as defenders, monster hunters, and military leaders for the Draconic Council. The dragonblades are elite combatants with a unique fighting style, harnessing the ancient and mystic powers of dragons. Most of these skilled warriors serve the Draconic Council and take on various roles, such as diplomats, gladiators, and monster hunters, fighting against the corruptive forces that threaten the world. Dragonblades are highly intelligent fighters, channeling the Draconic Power to perform exceptional feats of swordsmanship. Clad in heavy armor and often wielding shields, these warriors rely on their intellect rather than physical strength to dominate the battlefield. They often act on the frontline of battles, as well as protecting sacred sites, ancient treasures, and the Draconic Council's towers. Each dragonblade follows a Draconic Soul path, symbolized by a dragon color that bestows upon them elemental powers associated with that dragon. These elemental forces augment their martial prowess, enabling them to combat the sinister otherworldly forces threatening their world. Their cunning also allows them to serve as battle strategists, outwitting enemies and controlling the battlefield with strategic prowess. As the Malrokian Curse looms over Tanares, threatening to unleash chaos and devastation should large-scale battles erupt, dragonblades are required to avert such conflicts and hunt the cultists and aberrations that strive to cause them. Their missions demand extraordinary courage, tactical expertise, and unwavering dedication to the cause. In their quest, dragonblades often face formidable adversaries such as the Cult of Shadow Wing, which seeks to corrupt all creatures, including dragons, turning them into penumbral creatures that empower the eldritch Ungods. As the dragonblades grapple with their daunting tasks, the enigmatic Draconic Council is beset with internal strife, casting shadows over the future of Tanares. The Council's divisions stem from contrasting beliefs regarding the potential of mortals. The majestic Gold Avatar Dragon, Isendden, champions a faction that fervently trusts in mortal potential and destiny. In stark contrast, the formidable Black Avatar Dragon, Zaldrus, spearheads a faction that perceives mortals as feeble and susceptible to corruption. As this clandestine struggle for dominion over the council unfolds, whispers of political intrigue echoes in the Draconic Towers. Undeterred by these challenges, the dragonblades persevere in their mission. They venture into the Penumbral Plane to free captured dragons, dismantle the Shadow Wing's plans, and vanquish their foes. As the embodiment of strategic combat against the encroaching darkness, the dragonblades unleash their intellect, martial skill, and the awe-inspiring power of dragons to vanquish their foes.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 57 (Homebrew)

trait.name: Dragonblade History
trait.text: The dragonblades' origins can be traced back to the Godly Age, when dragons first shared their knowledge and power with mortals. Their original purpose was to increase the strength of mortals in the war against the Ungods' minions and protect Tanares, the world entrusted to the dragons by Tamera and Bauron. As time passed, the Ancient Age saw the creation of the Draconic Council, a powerful assembly of dragons, formed to preserve Tanares from penumbral corruption and the destructive Malrokian Curse. Upon its formation, the dragonblades became an essential component of the Draconic Council, serving as the backbone of their troops. Most have remained politically neutral, intervening only when the Council acted to prevent war or corruption. From their war-focused beginnings, the dragonblades have evolved into versatile agents, serving on the most diverse arrays of duties within the Council. During the Kemet Invasion, some dragonblades, recognizing the potential cataclysm, aided in the war effort against the invaders. Among them was the legendary dragonblade Sedura, a solitary warrior trained by a rogue master. Initially manipulated by D.E.A.T.H. to kill the Avatar Dragon Thyra, Sedura redeemed herself by becoming a war hero and helping Talessa and the Draconic Council thwart the Cult of Shadow Wing's attempt to corrupt other Avatar Dragons. In contemporary times, dragonblades operate as war-counselors and emissaries for various factions, with the Draconic Council allowing this to maintain influence and gather intelligence to prevent wars. Factions remain cautious about the dragonblades' loyalty to the Council, employing them as advisors and military leaders without revealing too much sensitive information. Facing hordes of sinister creatures, confronting the Shadow Wing, and other malevolent forces, the dragonblades use their unique skills and knowledge to prevent the return of the world-ending Ungods.

trait.name: The Draconic Council
trait.text:
The Draconic Council is the central governing body that oversees the dragonblades and their activities in the world of Tanares. When the gods Tamera and Bauron forged the world of Tanares, they created dragons as its guardians. However, because of mortal's hubris, the Ungods invaded Tanares, instigating conflicts and bringing the dangers of the Penumbral Plane. To protect Tanares from being consumed, the Draconic Council was established, composed of ancient dragons, the wise and powerful Talessa, and elite mortal dragonblades. The Avatar Dragons, named from their belief of being avatars of the gods' will to protect the world, hold the top positions within the Draconic Council, commanding the fight against the Ungods' minions. The dragonblades, in service to the Council, act as the main agents for the organization, being on the forefront of the battle against forces of the Penumbral Plane. Selected based on their courage and intellect, dragonblades undergo rigorous training to master martial prowess and unlock mystical abilities. Their most prominent members are given enchanted heavy armor and powerful mystically empowered weapons to serve the Council. Dragonblades act not only as battle-ready warriors but also as peacekeepers and ambassadors, in addition to leading groups to find and destroy the servants of the Ungods. The Council's primary adversary is the Cult of Shadow Wing, which intends to corrupt dragons and unleash the world-ending Ungods upon Tanares. Dragonblades combat them by foiling their political intrigue, locate and eradicate their cultists, confront penumbral creatures, and recover captured dragons and dragon's eggs. The Draconic Council is divided into two factions regarding mortals. One faction, led by Isendden and good alligned dragons, advocates cultivation and guidance, recognizing the potential heroism and strength of mortals. The other faction, distrustful of mortals, sees them as susceptible to corruption and advocates for control. This internal struggle shapes the Council's decisions and the missions undertaken by the dragonblades. Most dragonblades work under the Avatar Dragons as they hold the highest position in the hierarchy of the Council. As the dragonblades contribute to the fight against the Ungods' servants and their penumbral creatures, they may ascend through the Council's ranks, gaining access to better equipment, resources, and more challenging missions. Only the most powerful and dedicated dragonblades can achieve a vote in the Council, joining the esteemed ranks of the two current dragonblade voting members. The Council's hierarchy is based on merit, with seven ranks representing various roles and responsibilities:
• Avatar Dragon - Supreme Commanders of the Council (able to vote in council meetings) • Draconic Archon - Guardians of the Draconic Towers and Regional Commanders • Dragon Lord - Field Generals in charge of large-scale military operations • Dragon Commander - Leaders of a battalion (young dragons start here) • Dragon Captain - Commanders of a company within a battalion • Dragon Lieutenant - Platoon leaders responsible for a group of Soldiers • Dragon Soldier - Entry-level rank for mortal members
As they dedicate their efforts to rise in these ranks, the dragonblades stand as a bulwark against darkness, their intellect, combat skills, and raw draconic power crucial to the survival of Tanares. The fate of the world rests on their armored shoulders, and their unwavering dedication to the Draconic Council's mission will be one of the key factors in determining the destiny of dragons and mortals alike.

trait.name: D.E.A.T.H. to the Dragons
trait.text: In addition to their primary goal of protecting Tanares from the Ungods and their minions, the Draconic Council must also contend with extremist groups like D.E.A.T.H. Founded by individuals who have studied dragons for a long time, D.E.A.T.H. possesses many secrets about dragons, including the supposed plans and goals of some high-ranking members of the Draconic Council. This knowledge not only makes D.E.A.T.H. a dangerous adversary but also attracts those who seek to use this information against the Council. D.E.A.T.H. members believe that dragons are the source of the dreaded Malrokian Curse, which drives them to eliminate Avatar Dragons and disrupt the workings of the Draconic Council. Their misguided goal to rid Tanares of dragons has led to a long-standing conflict with the Council and its champions, the dragonblades. Unbeknownst to D.E.A.T.H., the Malrokian Curse is not the result of the dragons' existence but rather the machinations of the Ungods, who seek to sow chaos and destruction. D.E.A.T.H.'s extensive knowledge of dragons' secrets poses a unique challenge to the Council, as various factions may seek to steal or obtain this information for their own purposes. Even virtuous people might try to uncover such secrets to use them to foil the plans of evil dragons. Sometimes, members of the Council themselves may attempt to acquire information obtained by D.E.A.T.H. to use it against their oppositions within the Council, as the two factions led by Isendden and Zaldrus often struggle to agree on the best course of action. The dragonblades must navigate this complex landscape, dealing with D.E.A.T.H. and its influence on the politics of Tanares, while simultaneously confronting the looming threat of the Shadow Wing and the zealots of D.E.A.T.H. Engaged in a deadly game of deception and intrigue, the heroes of Tanares may find themselves drawn into D.E.A.T.H.'s schemes, lured into missions with unforeseen consequences. To ensure Tanares' safety and stability, the dragonblades must rely on their cunning and keen minds to deal with the forces of D.E.A.T.H., the machinations of the Shadow Wing, and potential treachery within the Draconic Council itself. Their ability to preserve the world from corruption depends on their unwavering dedication to the cause and their ability to adapt to ever-changing challenges.

trait.name: The Draconic Power
trait.text: At the core of the dragonblades' legendary prowess lies the enigmatic force known as Draconic Power. This mystical energy, derived from the ancient and enigmatic essence of dragons, elevates them beyond the capabilities of ordinary warriors and spellcasters, transcending the boundaries of normal magic, to grant unique fighting skills. To harness this formidable power, aspiring dragonblades must undergo rigorous training that melds the disciplines of the scholar, the strategist, and the front-line warrior. In their pursuit of mastery, these elite combatants embrace a curriculum inspired by ancient practices, focusing not only on martial arts but also on intellectual pursuits. They delve into the study of literature, calligraphy, general knowledge, and even the elegant art of poetry, refining their minds and honing their intellects. This comprehensive education shapes the dragonblades into versatile and adaptive warriors, capable of serving in a variety of roles, from skilled diplomats and cunning strategists to relentless monster hunters and inspiring counselors. Through their training, they acquire profound knowledge of the arcane, as well as the art of tracking and eliminating dangerous penumbral aberrations, which earns them bounties and increases their rank and influence within the Draconic Council. The journey to become a dragonblade begins with "The Dragon's Trial," a test held by the Council to assess the worthiness of potential recruits based on their intellect, physical abilities, morality, and loyalty to the Council's values. Those who pass the trial receive specialized training in harnessing the mystical force of dragons, perfecting their combat and tactical abilities. While many dragonblades are trained and serve under the guidance of the Draconic Council, others forge their paths independently or under the tutelage of dragons who have strayed from or never joined the Council. These independent dragonblades are often still recognized for their prowess and may collaborate with the Council on various tasks, working as penumbral monster hunters and collecting bounties. Despite their immense power and organization, the dragonblades must remain vigilant to ensure their ranks stay pure and uncorrupted. Sinister forces of corruption continually attempt to infiltrate the Draconic Council and subvert dragonblades, siphoning their Draconic Power to strengthen their penumbral dragons. As guardians, the dragonblades are tasked with remaining watchful, identifying corrupted individuals, and resisting the temptation to succumb to their enemies' alluring influence.

trait.name: Creating A Dragonblade
trait.text: The first step in creating your dragonblade character is to determine whether or not they are affiliated with the Draconic Council. Most dragonblades serve the Council, but there are many wandering dragonblades who could have served as the character's mentor. If they are affiliated with the Council, work with your Game Master to determine its ranking, who trained it and who is currently its superior, as well as the philosophy and goals of its group inside the Council. If they are not affiliated with the Council, work with your Game Master to determine the character's mentor, the mentor's history, and why they trained the character. Finally, decide what led your character to a life of adventure. Were they fulfilling a mission given to them by the Council? Did their studies make them question some of the things taught to them by their master or the Council? Did they encounter a group in need of their leadership that could help them achieve their personal goals? Did they embark on their adventure as part of their training?

feature.name: Starting Dragonblade
feature.text:
As a 1st-level Dragonblade, you begin play with 10 + your Constitution modifier hit points.
You are proficient with the following items, in addition to any proficiencies provided by your race or background.
• Armor: All armor, shields • Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons • Tools: Artisan tools (blacksmith) or artisan tools (cartographer) • Saving Throws: Intelligence, Constitution • Skills: Choose two skills from Arcana, History, Investigation, Nature, Perception, and Religion
You begin play with the following equipment, in addition to any equipment provided by your background.
• (a) one-handed martial weapon and a shield or (b) two-handed martial weapon • (a) chain mail or (b) chain shirt, longbow and 20 arrows • (a) a scholar's pack or (b) an explorer's pack
If you forgo this starting equipment, as well as the items offered by your background, you start with 5d4 × 10 gp to buy your equipment.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 58 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Multiclass Dragonblade
feature.text:
If your group uses the optional rule on multiclassing in the Player's Handbook, here's what you need to know if you choose dragonblade as one of your classes.
Ability Score Minimum: As a multiclass character, you must have at least 1 of the following ability score(s) to take a level in this class, or to take a level in another class if you are already a dragonblade.
• Constitution 13, and • Intelligence 13
Proficiencies Gained: When you gain your first level in a class other than your initial class, you gain only some of your new class's starting proficiencies, here are the proficiencies you gain when you take your first level as a fighter.
• Armor: light armor, medium armor, shields • Weapons: simple weapons, martial weapons • Tools: none
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 274 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Multiclass Features
feature.text:
When you gain a new level in a class, you get its features for that level. You don't, however, receive the class's starting equipment, and a few features have additional rules when you're multiclassing: Channel Divinity, Extra Attack, Unarmored Defense, and Spellcasting.
Channel Divinity: If you already have the Channel Divinity feature and gain a level in a class that also grants the feature, you gain the Channel Divinity effects granted by that class, but getting the feature again doesn't give you an additional use of it. You gain additional uses only when you reach a class level that explicitly grants them to you. For example, if you are a cleric 6/paladin 4, you can use Channel Divinity twice between rests because you are high enough level in the cleric class to have more uses. Whenever you use the feature, you can choose any of the Channel Divinity effects available to you from your two classes.
Extra Attack: If you gain the Extra Attack class feature from more than one class, the features don't add together. You can't make more than two attacks with this feature unless it says you do (as the fighter's version of Extra Attack does).
Similarly, the warlock's eldritch invocation Thirsting Blade doesn't give you additional attacks if you also have Extra Attack.
Unarmored Defense: If you already have the Unarmored Defense feature, you can't gain it again from another class.
Spellcasting: Your capacity for spellcasting depends partly on your combined levels in all your spellcasting classes and partly on your individual levels in those classes. Once you have the Spellcasting feature from more than one class, use the rules below. If you multiclass but have the Spellcasting feature from only one class, you follow the rules as described in that class.
Spells Known and Prepared: You determine what spells you know and can prepare for each class individually, as if you were a single-classed member of that class. If you are a ranger 4/wizard 3, for example, you know three 1 st-level ranger spells based on your levels in the ranger class. As a 3rd-level wizard, you know three wizard cantrips, and your spellbook contains ten wizard spells, two of which (the two you gained when you reached 3rd level as a wizard) can be 2nd-level spells. If your Intelligence is 16, you can prepare six wizard spells from your spellbook. Each spell you know and prepare is associated with one of your classes, and you use the spell casting ability of that class when you cast the spell. Similarly, a spellcasting focus, such as a holy symbol, can be used only for the spells from the class associated with that focus. If a cantrip of yours increases in power at higher levels, the increase is based on your character level, not your level in a particular class.
Spell Slots: You determine your available spell slots by adding together all your levels in the bard, cleric, druid, sorcerer, and wizard classes, half your levels (rounded down) in the paladin and ranger classes, and a third of your fighter or rogue levels (rounded down) if you have the Eldritch Knight or the Arcane Trickster feature. Use this total to determine your spell slots by consulting the Multiclass Spellcaster table. If you have more than one spellcasting class, this table might give you spell slots of a level that is higher than the spells you know or can prepare. You can use those slots, but only to cast your lower-level spells. If a lower level spell that you cast, like burning hands, has an enhanced effect when cast using a higher-level slot, you can use the enhanced effect, even though you don't have any spells of that higher level. For example, if you are the aforementioned ranger 4/ wizard 3, you count as a 5th-level character when determining your spell slots: you have four 1st-level slots, three 2nd-level slots, and two 3rd-level slots. However, you don't know any 3rd-level spells, nor do you know any 2nd-level ranger spells. You can use the spell slots of those levels to cast the spells you do know-and potentially enhance their effects.
Pact Magic: If you have both the Spellcasting class feature and the Pact Magic class feature from the warlock class, you can use the spell slots you gain from the Pact Magic feature to cast spells you know or have prepared from classes with the Spellcasting class feature, and you can use the spell slots you gain from the Spellcasting class feature to cast warlock spells you know.
Source: Player's Handbook (2014) p. 164

feature.name: Claws and Scales
feature.text:
At 1st level, your mastery allows the draconic energy to channel into your armor and weapon, turning them as innate to you as scales and claws are to a dragon. When you attack with melee or ranged weapons, you can use your Intelligence modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity, for the attack and damage rolls. Additionally, ignore the Strength requirement for wearing armor, and only consider half of its weight towards your carrying capacity
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 62 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Natural Strategist
feature.text:
At 1st level, you can tactically guide your allies. Whenever you roll for initiative at the start of a battle, prior to any combatant's first turn, and assuming you are not taken by surprise, you can use your reaction to maneuver your allies across the battlefield. If you do so, both you and all your allies within a 30-foot radius, who can hear your command, can instantly move up to 15 feet without provoking attacks of opportunity. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (at a minimum of once). You regain any spent use after completing a long rest.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 62 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Draconic Power
feature.text:
Your deep study and immersion made you able to comprehend the secret martial techniques known as Draconic Powers. They are divided into three types, each possessing one of these marks: Claw, Scale, and Wing. You can only use ONE Draconic Power per round unless you trigger Empowered Soul or the Draconic Power specifically permits it.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 62 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Draconic Power Progression
feature.text:
At 1st level, choose three 1st-level powers from the Draconic Powers list. They must be of different types (claw, scale or wings). The dragonblade table shows the number and max levels of Draconic Powers known, according to your class level. Starting at 2nd level, when you gain new powers or change one of your powers you must always have at least one power of each different type (claw, scale and wing). Starting at 8th level, whenever you gain a new level in this class, you can replace one Draconic Power you already know with a different power of a level that you can use. Additionally, starting at 2nd level, your chosen Draconic Soul will grant special Draconic Powers, according to the list in the Draconic Soul section. They do not count against the number of Draconic Powers you know, and you can't replace them with other Draconic Powers later.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 62 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Empowered Soul
feature.text:
Starting at 2nd level, whenever you use a Draconic Power, note down its mark, and once you have accumulated all three different marks, your soul becomes empowered.
• You can spend its empowerment to execute a Draconic Power that requires an action as a bonus action. When doing so, ignore the limitation of using only one Draconic Power per round.
• After using your Empowered status, you immediately delete all annotated marks and you can begin collecting them anew.
• You can conserve your Empowered status for a later turn.
• Every time you roll for initiative at the onset of a battle or finish a short or long rest, all previous marks are erased, and the Empowered status, if not already used, is lost.
Saving Throw and Spell Attack. Some Draconic Powers require the target to make a saving throw to resist the effects, or you may need to perform a spell attack to hit. The DC for the saving throw and the spell attack is calculated as follows:
Draconic Power DC = 8 + proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier.
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 62 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Draconic Soul
feature.text:
At 2nd level, you may choose an archetype that represents your combat training style: the Fury of the Red Dragon, the Integrity of the White Dragon, or the Celerity of the Blue Dragon. Each bestows upon you unique Draconic Powers and features at the 6th, 10th, 14th, and 18th levels. When a power refers to elements associated with your Draconic Soul, use fire for the red dragon, cold for the white dragon, and lightning for the blue dragon, according to your chosen type.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 65 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Draconic Power Progression Improvement (1st)
feature.text:
Starting at 2nd level, your chosen Draconic Soul will grant special Draconic Powers, according to the list in the Draconic Soul section. They do not count against the number of Draconic Powers you know, and you can't replace them with other Draconic Powers later.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 62 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Investigative Mind
feature.text:
Your abilities in research and study advance. At 3rd level, you acquire the Draconic language and gain proficiency in the Investigation skill. If you are already proficient, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability checks you make that uses this skill.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 65 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 65 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Draconic Knowledge
feature.text:
Your understanding of dragons intensifies. Starting at 5th level, whenever you perform an ability check with a skill that you are not proficient, add your proficiency bonus to the check if it is related to dragons.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 65 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Dragon Form
feature.text:
Starting at 9th level, you can use your action to magically transform into a dragon form. After the transformation, you can only use this feature again after a long rest. Your dragonblade level determines the power of the dragon you can transform into, as shown in the Dragon Form table. Your dragon form's aspect matches your Draconic Soul.
Dragon Form: Dragonblade Level | Dragon Form 9th | Juvenile Dragon Form 12th | Mature Dragon Form 15th | Adult Dragon Form 18th | Old Dragon Form
You can stay in the dragon form for 10 minutes then revert to your normal form. You can revert to your normal form earlier by using a bonus action on your turn. You automatically revert if you fall unconscious, drop to 0 hit points, or die. While you are transformed, the following rules apply:
• Your game statistics are replaced by the statistics of the dragon form, but you retain your alignment, personality, and Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. You also retain all of your skill and saving throw proficiencies, in addition to gaining those of the dragon form. If the dragon form has the same proficiency as you and the bonus in its stat block is higher than yours, use the dragon form's bonus instead of yours.
• When you transform, you assume the dragon form's hit points and Hit Dice. When you revert to your normal form, you return to the number of hit points you had before you transformed. However, if you revert as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to your normal form. For example, if you take 10 damage in dragon form and have only 1 hit point left, you revert and take 9 damage. As long as the excess damage doesn't reduce your normal form to 0 hit points, you aren't knocked unconscious.
• You can't perform Draconic Powers or cast spells, and your ability to take any action is limited to the capabilities of the dragon form. Transforming doesn't break your concentration on a spell you've already cast.
• You retain the benefit of any features from your class, species, or other source and can use them if the new form is physically capable of doing so. However, you can't use any of your special senses, such as darkvision, unless your new form also has that sense.
• You choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal, but the GM decides whether it is practical for the new form to wear a piece of equipment. Your equipment doesn't change size or shape to match the new form, and any equipment that the new form can't wear must either fall to the ground or merge with it. Equipment that merges with the form has no effect until you leave the form.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 65 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Call of the Dragon
feature.text:
At 20th level, your bond with the power of dragons is so potent that these majestic creatures respond to your call for combat. You can summon an adult dragon to assist you in a fight. The dragon takes 1d4 rounds to reach you, but it can only be called if its arrival is feasible. The dragon's color matches that of your Draconic Soul and it aids you in the most effective manner possible. It remains until the conflict or the cause of its summoning ends (as per the GM's discretion) and no longer than 30 days. Once used, this ability cannot be invoked again until a 30-day period has passed.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 65 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Draconic Soul: Celerity of the Blue Dragon
feature.text:
Dragonblades who have mastered the Celerity of the Blue Dragon soar through the skies like fearless tempests, their bodies crackling with the power of lightning and thunder. These daring wanderers travel the world, driven by a thirst for adventure and the thrill of exploring uncharted territories. The winds that sweep across the open skies still sing with the echoes of the once-mighty Eternal Storm, a testament to the incredible power that once raged in the west of Tanares. But for the dragonblades who have embraced this path, the elemental force that courses through the air is a call to adventure, a siren's song to be explored and harnessed. These untamed wanderers are graceful as a summer breeze, their movements as fluid and precise as the winds they control. They are drawn to the untamed energy of the storms, seeking to understand its secrets and bend it to their will. Despite the disappearance of Thyra, the Blue Avatar Dragon, these dragonblades pay homage to their legacy with each daring leap into the unknown, their courage, determination, and mastery of the elements, making them the true masters of the skies and the embodiment of freedom.
Blue Dragon Draconic Powers: Dragonblade Level | Draconic Power 2nd | Lightning Dash 4th | Tail Slam 7th | Binding Lightning 10th | Lagging Thunder 13th | Thundering Translocation 16th | Shocking Trap 19th | Spartial Storm
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 67 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Empowered Wind Blast (Celerity of the Blue Dragon)
feature.text:
Starting at 2nd level, each time your soul becomes Empowered, you can channel a portion of its energy to unleash a gust of wind against a creature you can see within 30 feet of you. The creature's speed is reduced by 10 feet for 1 minute, and it must make a Dexterity saving throw with a DC equivalent to your Draconic Power save DC. On a failing, the creature falls prone. In addition, while the creature's movement is impeded by this effect, it cannot benefit from any spell or item that amplifies its speed.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 67 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Thunderous Assault (Celerity of the Blue Dragon)
feature.text:
At 6th level, you allow your allies to capitalize on your enemies' vulnerabilities. When a creature is knocked prone as a result of failing its save against your Empowered Wind Blast, one willing creature that you can see within 30 feet of you is allowed to use its reaction to move up to 30 feet and make a weapon attack against the prone creature.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 67 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Wings of Celerity (Celerity of the Blue Dragon)
feature.text:
Starting at 10th level, you enhance your allies' agility to bolster their defenses. You and all willing creatures of your choice within 30 feet of you have advantage on Dexterity saving throws.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 67 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Lightning Immunity (Celerity of the Blue Dragon)
feature.text:
At 14th level, the electric power coursing through you grants you immunity to lightning damage.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 67 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Winged Fury (Celerity of the Blue Dragon)
feature.text:
At 18th level, your flying speed derived from the Spiritual Wings feature increases to 90 feet. In addition, you acquire the Wing Attack legendary action of an ancient blue dragon, which you can use as an action when your Spiritual Wings are activated.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 67 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Draconic Soul: Fury of the Red Dragon
feature.text:
Dragonblades are the shock troops of the Draconic Council, and the Fury of the Red Dragon is one of the most aggressive and intense training styles within their ranks. These warriors are forged by dragon fire in the art of war and are trained to lead the assault against their enemies. Those who choose this path are experts in battle, and their relentless aggression is unmatched. Whether it be scorching heat or raging infernos, the Fury of the Red Dragon dragonblades are capable of withstanding the harshest scorching conditions, making them ideal for missions in South Tanares. They seek to study the ways of the red dragon and learn from their mastery of the environment. These warriors are the embodiment of dragon-like ferocity, and they are feared and respected by friends and foes alike.
Red Dragon Draconic Powers: Dragonblade Level | Draconic Power 2nd | Burning Strike 4th | Sundering Strike 7th | Ring of Fire 10th | Boon of Flames 13th | Blades of Wind 16th | Sweltering Heat 19th | Final Destruction
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 66 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Empowered Dragon's Fury (Fury of the Red Dragon)
feature.text:
Starting at 2nd level, you can channel a portion of your Empowered Soul energy to unleash your fiery fury. Each time your soul becomes Empowered by Draconic Power, you can immediately release fire on a creature you can see within 30 feet of you. Make a ranged attack roll against it; if you hit, the creature takes 1d6 fire damage for every two dragonblade levels you possess, rounded down.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 66 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Mark of the revenge (Fury of the Red Dragon)
feature.text:
Starting at 6th level, when you expend your Empowered Soul to execute a second Draconic Power in a single turn, you may retain a mark (Claw, Scale, or Wing) of your choice instead of erasing all of them.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 66 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Superior Maintenance (Fury of the Red Dragon)
feature.text:
At 10th level, your aura ignites the resilience of your allies. When any creatures of your choice within 30 feet of you are targeted by a spell that requires a saving throw, they may choose to replace their saving throw ability modifier with your Intelligence modifier (the target still uses its proficiency and any other applicable bonuses, effects, and conditions for this roll).
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 66 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Fire Immunity (Fury of the Red Dragon)
feature.text:
At 14th level, the flame power coursing through you renders you immune to fire damage.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 66 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Draconic Presence (Fury of the Red Dragon)
feature.text:
At the 18th level, you acquire the Frightful Presence ability of an ancient red dragon, which you can use as an action.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 66 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Draconic Soul: Integrity of the White Dragon
feature.text:
Dragonblades trained in the Integrity of the White Dragon are the sentinels of the frozen tundra, their bodies honed to withstand the freezing winds of the north. They are the guardians of sacred places, their forms standing like bastions of ice and steel against all who would dare threaten the Draconic Council's interests. Embodying the resilience and cunning of the white dragon, these warriors venture deep into the heart of the frosty wilds, braving blizzards that rage like a tempest, scaling icy cliffs as if they were steps to the heavens. Every step they take is a testament to their unwavering determination, every breath a reminder of their fierce loyalty. With each battle, they hone their bodies to be more attuned to the ways of the white dragon, drawing upon its mastery of the environment to survive where others would perish. Their movements are graceful, yet deadly, like the flow of ice upon a frozen river. They are the protectors of dragon lairs, their eyes constantly scanning the horizon, their senses alert for any sign of danger. The sight of a dragonblade trained in the Integrity of the White Dragon is both fearsome and awe-inspiring. Their determination shines like diamonds in the snow, their resolve shields its allies in the bleakest of environments. These warriors are the guardians of the Draconic Council, their unwavering spirit a reminder that even in the face of the coldest winter, the zeal of protection and defense burns bright.
White Dragon Draconic Powers: Dragonblade Level | Draconic Power 2nd | Shield of Scales 4th | Enduring Scales 7th | Frozen Spikes 10th | Frost Burst 13th | Protecting Mists 16th | Aura of the Scales 19th | Ice Fortress
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 66 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Empowered Dragon's Protection (Integrity of the White Dragon)
feature.text:
At 2nd level, you can channel a portion of your Empowered Soul energy to form an icy shield, protecting you from an enemy's attack. The first time you sustain damage after your soul becomes Empowered, you may choose to reduce the damage by 1d8 for every two dragonblade levels you possess (only if you are still Empowered, and to a minimum of 0).
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 67 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Ice Veins (Integrity of the White Dragon)
feature.text:
At 6th level, when you expend your Empowered Soul to execute a second Draconic Power in a turn, a creature of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you suffers a 1d4 penalty to all its attack rolls until the end of its next turn.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 67 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Winter Mantle (Integrity of the White Dragon)
feature.text:
At 10th level, your soul extends its protection to your allies. All creatures of your choice (including yourself) within 30 feet of you gain resistance to cold, acid, and poison damage.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 67 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Cold Immunity (Integrity of the White Dragon)
feature.text:
At 14th level, the icy power coursing through you grants you immunity to cold damage.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 67 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Preservation (Integrity of the White Dragon)
feature.text:
At 18th level, all willing creatures of your choice within 30 feet of you have advantage in death saving throws. Additionally, at the start of each of your turns, all creatures of your choice within 30 feet of you that are at 0 hit points regain 1d4 hit points.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 67 (Homebrew)
